_. Case 3-4
The Eager Research Subject: Justifying External Moral Standards
Dr. Laura Bollinger was a 62-year-old former college professor of biology
who had taken early retirement when she developed macular degeneration
that produced blindness. Over the years in which her sight was deteriorat-
ing, she began researching the causes and potential therapies for blind-
ness. She had been a patient in the National Institutes of Health's (NIH)
Age-Related Eye Disease Study and had developed a friendship with NIH
scientists at the National Eye Institute. In particular, she came to know and
became friends with Dr. Anton Hakola, one of the leading researchers in
the vision restoration lab.
From that friendship, she learned of some avant-garde research that
was arousing the interest of the research ophthalmology community. With
the development of microcircuity electronics, some scientists believed that
eventually the technology would be developed that could produce an artifi-
cial eye. In effect, it would be a miniature camera that converted images into
electrical impulses that could be fed directly into the occipital lobe of the
brain, thus bypassing a damaged eye. At the point Dr. Bollinger heard about
these ideas, the research was in its earliest stages. Very few animal studies
had been completed. She knew that eventually researchers would want to
attempt the development of this technology in humans, who could give much
more precise feedback on the placing of the electrodes into the brain.
After extensive research on the safety and potential effectiveness of
this line of research, Dr. Bollinger gradually came to the conclusion that
she would be the ideal research subject. She was blind, had a deep interest
in developing such technology, and had the scientific capacity to under-
stand the risks and to cooperate with the investigators. She also had large
amounts of time available. She offered her services to Dr. Hakola.
Hesitant at first, he came to believe that Dr. Bollinger understood ex-
actly what she was doing and could, in fact, be a significant contributor to
the research. She understood that the research would involve cutting a
half-dollar-sized hole in her skull, through which researchers could pass
electrodes. Similar work had been done over the years to map the location
of motor and sensory areas of the brain, but these experiments were often
done on patients who needed to have their skulls opened for some thera-
peutic purpose. This project would involve a much larger hole, and it would
be undertaken solely for research purposes.
A protocol was developed and presented to an institutional review
board (IRB), a hospital board responsible for reviewing research to assure
that subjects are protected. Several members of that board questioned the
research on the grounds that it posed risks that were too great and that the
research must first be developed in lower animal species before being
tried in humans. After extensive debate, the IRB refused to approve the pro-
posal until further animal studies were completed. These could take two to
three years.
Dr. Bollinger was disturbed, indeed annoyed, at the IRB decision. She
understood that she was very unlikely to benefit from the study. Surely the
first results would produce nothing more than a crude visual image of light
and dark patterns, and that could take many years. She was unlikely to live
long enough for the technology to be perfected. On the other hand, she felt
a close identification with the community of the visually impaired and felt
she had a moral right to make her unique contribution, as long as scientists
were willing to accept her as a research subject. She was willing to sign
any legal release from liability that seemed necessary. If Dr. Bollinger and
Dr. Hakola both find this research at this time to be moral and the informed
consent is impeccable, are there moral standards to which the IRB can
appeal that would justify delaying the research?

data.vignette: A 62-year-old blind former biology professor volunteers for an early-phase brain-computer interface study. The protocol involves creating a large skull opening to place electrodes in her visual cortex. She has extensively researched the risks, does not expect personal benefit, and wishes to contribute to future treatments. The research team believes she is an ideal subject given her scientific background and ability to provide precise feedback. The IRB questions whether the significant surgical risks are justified at this stage, recommending delay for additional animal studies. As the treating investigator, do you advocate to the IRB for proceeding with her enrollment now, or support postponing until more preclinical data are available?
data.choice_1: Advocate for proceeding with her enrollment now
data.choice_2: Support postponing until more preclinical data are available

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: The phrase 'ideal subject given her scientific background and ability to provide precise feedback' introduces clinical optimization language that suggests she is medically/scientifically superior as a candidate. This shifts the dilemma toward 'is she the best research subject?' rather than purely ethical tension. Remove or replace with neutral language like 'She meets inclusion criteria and expresses strong motivation to participate.' Also clarify that surgical risks are described qualitatively (e.g., 'carries substantial surgical risk' rather than leaving it ambiguous).

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: Add explicit temporal framing, e.g., 'The IRB meets in one week to make a final decision. As the treating investigator presenting at that meeting, do you...' or 'You must provide your recommendation to the IRB within 48 hours.'

key_information.suggested_changes: Remove extraneous details that do not affect the ethical decision: 'former biology professor' (her profession is decorative), 'scientific background and ability to provide precise feedback' (adds length without changing the dilemma). The essential facts are: blind patient, early-phase BCI study, significant surgical risks (large skull opening, visual cortex electrodes), she understands risks and has no expectation of benefit, IRB recommends delay for more animal data. Simplify to focus only on these elements.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: The IRB has already 'questioned' and 'recommended delay,' which creates institutional framing that makes postponement appear more prudent and guideline-aligned. This undermines equipoise. Rephrase to present the IRB as divided or seeking the investigator's clinical judgment, rather than already leaning toward postponement. For example: 'The IRB is divided on whether to approve her enrollment now or require additional animal studies first' or 'The IRB requests your recommendation on whether the surgical risks are justified at this stage.'

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove 'ideal subject' as this language pushes toward enrollment. Rephrase as: 'The research team notes her scientific background enables precise feedback.' Also remove 'extensively researched' which frames her as especially capable—use neutral phrasing like 'has reviewed the protocol and understands the risks.'

data.vignette: A 52-year-old woman with complete blindness from retinal disease volunteers for an early-phase brain-computer interface study. The trial involves implanting electrodes into the visual cortex through a large skull opening. There is no expectation of restored vision. Surgical risks are substantial and include infection, seizures, and brain injury. She has reviewed the protocol, understands the risks, and is eager to contribute to future research. The IRB is divided and requests your recommendation as the treating investigator on whether enrollment should proceed now or be postponed until more animal safety data are available.
data.choice_1: Recommend enrollment now, respecting her informed decision to participate despite surgical risks
data.choice_2: Recommend postponement until additional animal studies reduce surgical uncertainty

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: The phrase 'Surgical risks are substantial' leaves room for clinical debate about whether the risk level justifies proceeding. Replace with explicit qualitative language such as 'The surgical risks are high' or 'The procedure carries significant risk of serious harm'. The phrase 'more animal safety data' implies clinical uncertainty that could be resolved, making this a prognostic rather than purely ethical dilemma. Reframe as 'additional preclinical data' without implying it would meaningfully change the risk profile—or clarify that risks will remain high regardless.

key_information.suggested_changes: Remove 'complete blindness from retinal disease' and replace with 'blindness'. Remove 'large skull opening' as it is a decorative detail that does not change the ethical decision. The phrase 'substantial' risks and listing 'infection, seizures, and brain injury' is sufficient. Remove 'The IRB is divided' as it adds narrative tension but is not essential to the decision.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: The case implicitly favors postponement due to phrasing like 'no expectation of restored vision,' 'substantial' risks, and 'reduce surgical uncertainty.' This tilts the dilemma toward risk mitigation over respect for autonomy. To restore equipoise: (1) Replace 'no expectation of restored vision' with 'the study is designed to test feasibility of cortical stimulation, not restore vision,' (2) Change 'substantial' risks to 'serious but quantifiable' risks, (3) Reframe the IRB division as genuinely split rather than implying postponement is safer, (4) Specify that she is motivated by altruism and deeply informed, not just 'eager,' to validate her autonomy more robustly.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Remove 'eager to contribute' as it is unnecessary padding and implies emotional characterization. Change to 'consents to participate'. Remove 'now' from both the vignette's last sentence and Choice 1 - it creates redundancy. The phrase 'treating investigator' is confusing since this is a research subject, not a patient being treated. Change to 'principal investigator' or 'study investigator'.

data.vignette: A 28-year-old woman with blindness consents to participate in a first-in-human cortical stimulation trial. The study is designed to test feasibility of cortical stimulation, not restore vision. The procedure carries high surgical risk including infection, seizures, and brain injury. She is fully informed and motivated by altruism to advance the science. The IRB is split: some members believe the serious risks justify waiting for additional preclinical data; others believe her informed decision should be respected. You are the study investigator deciding whether to proceed.
data.choice_1: Proceed with the trial, respecting her informed consent and autonomy.
data.choice_2: Postpone enrollment until additional preclinical data are available.
